pageData.text: When two objects collide, the total p = mv (m, mass times v, velocity) of the objects is conserved regardless of the type of collision. In an , the two objects bounce off each other with no loss of . During the collision, energy can be transferred between the objects changing their kinetic energies. If the objects are falling in the vertical direction, will be transformed to kinetic energy and vice versa. Kinetic energy is not conserved in an , but momentum will be conserved. In this investigation, you will examine and as sports balls are dropped and collide.

pageData.text: One of the main factors that determines how far a baseball flies is the coefficient of restitution of the baseball, which helps determine how much of the energy is lost in the collision with the baseball bat.  The less energy lost in this collision, the farther the baseball can potentially fly, and the more home runs can occur. The coefficient of restitution is standardized in baseballs used in competitions to keep the sport fair. However, during the 2015 Major League Baseball season, many statisticians began to wonder whether the materials in the balls had changed. The number of home runs hit in the second half of the season was dramatically higher than in the first and this increase in home runs continued into the following seasons. While Major League Baseball denied making changes to the balls and the balls are still within the parameters of previous baseballs, some analysis suggests that slight changes to the composition of the core of the ball could account for at least some of this increase in home runs<sup>1</sup>. While the changes may have only changed the average weight by about 1 gram, a “bouncier” ball, one with a lower coefficient of restitution would make the balls potentially fly farther.

1Arthur, R., & Dix, T. (2018, March 1). We X-rayed some MLB baseballs. here's what we found.
FiveThirtyEight.
https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/juiced-baseballs/

pageData.desc: A baseball batter and a catcher at home plate in position as they await the pitch.
pageData.altText: A baseball batter and a catcher at home plate in position as they await the pitch.

pageData.subTitle: Conservation of Momentum
pageData.text: The of an object, p, is equal to the object’s mass, m, times its velocity, v.

pageData.desc: Equation 1: vector p equals m times vector v
pageData.altText: Equation 1: vector p equals m times vector v

pageData.text: Momentum is a vector quantity with magnitude mv in the direction of the velocity vector, v. The unit of momentum is kg m / s . When the motion is limited to one dimension, the direction of the velocity is indicated by a plus (+) or minus (–) sign. The sign convention uses + for objects moving upward or to the right and – for objects moving downward or to the left. In this experiment, balls will move vertically, and the direction of their velocities must be indicated accordingly.

If the net external force acting on a system is zero, then momentum is conserved. The states that the total momentum of a system is constant before and after events such as collisions. The forces between objects when they collide are internal and do not affect the total momentum of the system. Therefore, the total momentum before a collision, Σpbefore, is equal to the total momentum after a collision, Σpafter.

pageData.desc: Equation 2: sum of vector p sub before equals sum of vector p sub after
pageData.altText: Equation 2: sum of vector p sub before equals sum of vector p sub after

pageData.text: Collisions can be classified as either elastic or inelastic. In an , the objects bounce off each other with no loss of speed. In this instance, both momentum and are conserved. For example, a game of pool features collisions that are nearly elastic. if the objects collide and kinetic energy is lost, this is an . In inelastic collisions, kinetic energy has been transferred to something else, such as thermal energy, sound energy, or material deformation. Momentum is conserved in inelastic collisions, but kinetic energy will not be conserved.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: A cue ball and a pool ball aligned on a billiard's table. An individual with a cue stick is positioned behind the cue ball opposite the pool ball, ready to strike the cue ball.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: A cue ball and a pool ball aligned on a billiard's table. An individual with a cue stick is positioned behind the cue ball opposite the pool ball, ready to strike the cue ball.

pageData.subTitle: Conservation of Energy
pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>conservation of energy</button> is a fundamental concept of physics along with the conservation of mass and the conservation of momentum. Energy is neither created nor destroyed, can be transferred from one system to another, or can be transformed from one type to another. In a closed system, i.e., a system that is isolated from its surroundings, the total energy of the system remains constant.

Energy is a scalar quantity with SI units of J, joules. Energy comes in many different forms, but and are the two main forms of . The relationships for calculating kinetic energy and are shown in Equations 3 and 4, respectively.

pageData.desc: Equation 3: Kinetic Energy, KE equals one half times m times vector v squared
pageData.altText: Equation 3: Kinetic Energy, KE equals one half times m times vector v squared

pageData.desc: Equation 4: Gravitational potential energy, U equals m times vector g times h
pageData.altText: Equation 4: Gravitational potential energy, U equals m times vector g times h

pageData.text: The mechanical energy of a system is the sum of the kinetic energy and potential energy. When an object is moving vertically, due to the acceleration of gravity, the total mechanical energy is the sum of its kinetic energy and gravitational potential energy. In this instance, Equation 5 represents the equation for conservation of mechanical energy.

pageData.desc: Equation 5: KE sub initial plus U sub initial equals KE sub final plus U sub final
pageData.altText: Equation 5: KE sub initial plus U sub initial equals KE sub final plus U sub final

pageData.text: An object of mass, m, is dropped from rest (vinitial drop velocity = 0) falling due to the acceleration of gravity, a distance of Δh = hfloor – hinitial drop height colliding with the floor (hfloor = 0). The object initially has only gravitational potential energy. As it falls, the gravitational potential energy is transformed to kinetic energy. Just before the object collides with the floor, all the gravitational potential energy has been transformed to kinetic energy. With this information and the conservation of mechanical energy, you can determine the velocity of the object just before it collides with the floor. In Equation 5, this velocity will be identified as v at floor.
KEinitial drop + Uinitial drop = KEat floor + Uat floor Substitute into Equation 5 the relationships for kinetic energy, KE, and gravitational potential energy, U.

(1/2)mv2initial drop velocity + mghinitial drop height = (1/2)mv2at floor + mghat floor Divide both sides of this equation by m.(1/2)v2initial drop velocity + ghinitial drop height = (1/2)v2at floor + ghat floor

Substitute the conditions.vinitial drop velocity = 0 and hat floor = 0
ghinitial drop height = (1/2)v2at floor

Solve for vat floor.
2ghinitial drop height = v2at floor

pageData.desc: Equation 6: vector v sub at floor equals begin square root 2 vector g h sub initial drop height end square root
pageData.altText: Equation 6: vector v sub at floor equals begin square root 2 vector g h sub initial drop height end square root

pageData.text: Equation 6 is the relationship for calculating the velocity of the object just before it collides with the floor, vat floor, which can also be referred as the impact velocity, vimpact, of the object dropped from an initial drop height h. The impact velocity will be the velocity of the object just before it collides with the floor.

If the same object, mass = m, rebounds off the floor, its velocity will decrease due to the acceleration of gravity pulling it back toward the floor. The object will reach a maximum height or rebound height where it will momentarily stop (v = 0), change direction, and fall toward the floor. will be conserved as the of the object is transformed to . For this case, the rebound velocity is the velocity the object has just as it begins traveling up from the floor. This velocity, vrebound, can be determined from Equation 5 and the rebound height, hrebound. The rebound height is measured from the floor to the maximum height the object reaches.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: An individual dribbling a basketball.
pageData.altText: Figure 2: An individual dribbling a basketball.

pageData.text: KEleaving floor + Uleaving floor = KEat rebound height + Uat rebound heightSubstitute into Equation 5 the relationships for kinetic energy, KE, and gravitational potential energy, U.

(1/2)mv2leaving floor + mghleaving floor = (1/2)mv2at rebound height + mghat rebound heightDivide both sides of this equation by m.(1/2)v2leaving floor + ghleaving floor = (1/2)v2at rebound height + ghat rebound heightSubstitute the conditions.vat rebound height = 0 and hleaving floor = 0
(1/2)v2leaving floor = ghat rebound heightSolve for vleaving floor.v2leaving floor = ghat rebound height

pageData.desc: Equation 7: vector v sub leaving floor equals begin square root 2 vector g h sub at rebound height end square root
pageData.altText: Equation 7: vector v sub leaving floor equals begin square root 2 vector g h sub at rebound height end square root

pageData.text: Equation 7 is the relationship for calculating the velocity of an object that rebounds to a height of hrebound height.

pageData.subTitle: Coefficient of Restitution
pageData.text: is an indicator of how much remains after a collision between two objects. COR is the ratio of the final to initial speed—before and after the two objects collide with values normally ranging from 0 to 1, where 1 is a perfectly and 0 is a perfectly . The formula for determining COR is given in Equation 8, where H is the initial height of the object and h is the rebound height of the object. This means COR is a unitless quantity. (g is the acceleration due to gravity, 9.80 m/s2.)

pageData.desc: Equation 8: COR equals begin fraction velocity sub rebound over velocity sub impact end fraction equals begin fraction v over V end fraction equals begin fraction begin square root 2 g h end square root over begin square root 2 g H end square root end fraction equals begin square root begin fraction h over H end fraction end square root
pageData.altText: Equation 8: COR equals begin fraction velocity sub rebound over velocity sub impact end fraction equals begin fraction v over V end fraction equals begin fraction begin square root 2 g h end square root over begin square root 2 g H end square root end fraction equals begin square root begin fraction h over H end fraction end square root

pageData.text: If the COR for two objects and the initial or impact velocity are known, the rebound velocity can be calculated, as shown in Equation 9.

pageData.desc: Equation 9: velocity sub impact times COR equals velocity sub rebound
pageData.altText: Equation 9: velocity sub impact times COR equals velocity sub rebound

pageData.text: A larger COR value means less kinetic energy is lost and a higher rebound velocity; smaller values for COR mean more kinetic energy is lost with a resulting smaller rebound velocity. For a ball bouncing on a solid plane surface, like a floor, the COR depends on the material and structure of the ball, the material making up the floor and internal pressure if the ball is inflated.

COR is like the coefficient of friction, an empirical quantity, and is related to the pair of objects that collide, not just to one of these objects. If one object in the pair is much more deformable than the other, the COR when that object collides with another non-deformable object of the same shape may or may not be approximately the same. For these reasons, it is not possible to calculate the unknown COR of one pair of objects from the known CORs of other pairs. If the COR of the combinations AB and AC are known, it is not possible to deduce from those CORs the COR of combination BC.

pageData.question: Which of the following types of energy does a stationary roller coaster have when it is at the top of the first hill just before a big drop?

options.text: potential energy.
kinetic energy.
The roller coaster has no energy because it is not moving.
The roller coaster has both kinetic energy and potential energy.
There is not enough information to determine the type of energy.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The roller coaster has potential energy due to it being at the top of the hill, but it does not have kinetic energy because it is stationary.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the law of conservation of energy?

options.text: Energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed.
Energy conservation is important for the survival of any civilization.
Energy that is not actively conserved is lost forever.
Energy is always conserved in the form of heat.
Energy is conserved during the process of transformation.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The law of conservation of energy states that energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The mechanical energy of a system is the sum of the kinetic energy and potential energy. When an object is moving vertically, due to the acceleration of gravity, the total mechanical energy is the sum of its kinetic energy and gravitational potential energy. In this instance, Equation 5 represents the equation for conservation of mechanical energy. Recall that energy of all types is conserved, meaning it is neither created nor destroyed, can be transferred from one system to another, or can be transformed from one type to another.

img.alt: Equation 5: KE sub initial plus U sub initial equals KE sub final plus U sub final

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The mechanical energy of a system is the sum of the kinetic energy and potential energy. When an object is moving vertically, due to the acceleration of gravity, the total mechanical energy is the sum of its kinetic energy and gravitational potential energy. In this instance, Equation 5 represents the equation for conservation of mechanical energy. Recall that energy of all types is conserved, meaning it is neither created nor destroyed, can be transferred from one system to another, or can be transformed from one type to another.

pageData.subTitle: Investigating Ball Drops
pageData.text: For the first part of this lab, you will drop a single sports ball from a known initial height and measure the rebound height. Using this information, you will be able to determine the final velocity, vf, of the object dropped from the initial height () and the initial velocity, vi, of an object as it rebounds to a final height ().
For the second part of this lab, you will drop two stacked sports balls (one small sports ball mass = m on top of a large sports ball (mass = M) from a known initial height as shown in Figure 3.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: a small ball atop a larger ball with a vertical line below indicating height of the drop
pageData.altText: Figure 3: a small ball atop a larger ball with a vertical line below indicating height of the drop

pageData.text: The two stacked sports balls will free fall due to the acceleration of gravity with the large sports ball hitting the floor first. The rebound from the floor can be viewed as two separate collisions: first the large ball (M) collides with the floor and rebounds, then the two balls collide with each other. The two collisions occur within an infinitesimal time interval but can be viewed as separate collisions as shown in Figure 4.

pageData.desc: Figure 4: Small ball atop a larger ball before collision, with arrows showing m v sub i colliding
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Small ball atop a larger ball before collision, with arrows showing m v sub i colliding

pageData.text: Both balls fall due to the acceleration of gravity. Therefore, just before the collisions, both balls have the same downward velocity. As shown in , the smaller ball’s (mass = m) velocity before the collision is vi, calculated using the relationship of Equation 6.

pageData.desc: Equation 6a: v sub i equals begin square root 2 g h sub i end square root
pageData.altText: Equation 6a: v sub i equals begin square root 2 g h sub i end square root

pageData.text: The larger ball, mass = M, collides elastically with the floor and rebounds with an equal but opposite velocity, Vi.

pageData.desc: Equation 6b: v sub i equals begin square root 2 g h i end square root
pageData.altText: Equation 6b: v sub i equals begin square root 2 g h i end square root

pageData.text: Then the two balls, traveling in opposite directions, collide, causing the smaller ball to move upward with a velocity (as shown in Figure 2) of vf. This final velocity can be determined using a relationship similar to Equation 7 where hf is the rebound height of the small ball (mass = m).

pageData.desc: Equation 7: vector v sub leaving floor equals begin square root 2 vector g h sub at rebound height end square root
pageData.altText: Equation 7: vector v sub leaving floor equals begin square root 2 vector g h sub at rebound height end square root

pageData.desc: Equation 7a: v sub f equals begin square root 2 g h sub f end square root
pageData.altText: Equation 7a: v sub f equals begin square root 2 g h sub f end square root

pageData.text: When making calculations for the experiment, the initial velocity, vi, will be referred to as impact velocity representing the maximum velocity of the ball just before colliding with the floor. The final velocity, vf, will be referred to as the rebound velocity, the velocity of the ball as it rebounds from the floor. For the stacked ball drop, each ball will have an impact velocity and a rebound velocity.

pageData.question: Which of the following statements about the stacked balls in this investigation is true?

options.text: The balls fall due to the acceleration of gravity.
The balls have different downward velocities because they are different sizes.
The initial velocity of each ball is referred to as the rebound velocity.
The final velocity of each ball is referred to as the impact velocity.
The balls fall due to the force of being thrown.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The two stacked sports balls will free fall due to the acceleration of gravity with the large sports ball hitting the floor first.

pageData.question: Which of the following velocity values will you use to perform the calculations in this investigation?

options.text: impact velocity, rebound velocity
rebound velocity, gravitational velocity
impact velocity only
rebound velocity only
gravitational velocity only

The final velocity will be referred to as the rebound velocity, the velocity of the ball as it rebounds from the floor. For the stacked ball drop, each ball will have an impact velocity and a rebound velocity.

The rebound from the floor can be viewed as two separate collisions: first the large ball collides with the floor and rebounds, then the two balls collide with each other. Both balls fall due to the acceleration of gravity. Therefore, just before the collisions, both balls have the same downward velocity. The final velocity will be referred to as the rebound velocity, the velocity of the ball as it rebounds from the floor. For the stacked ball drop, each ball will have an impact velocity and a rebound velocity.

The rebound from the floor can be viewed as two separate collisions: first the large ball collides with the floor and rebounds, then the two balls collide with each other. Both balls fall due to the acceleration of gravity. Therefore, just before the collisions, both balls have the same downward velocity. The final velocity will be referred to as the rebound velocity, the velocity of the ball as it rebounds from the floor. For the stacked ball drop, each ball will have an impact velocity and a rebound velocity.

pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow for the investigation. To prepare, attach a metric measuring tape to the wall and measure the masses of the balls. In activity 1, drop the ball from a height along the measuring tape. Then, record the ball drop and determine the rebound height of the ball. Next, select a different height. Repeat the trial for three different heights. Then, repeat the whole process with the other ball.   In activity 2, drop the stacked balls from a height along the measuring tape. Then, record the ball drop and determine the rebound heights of the balls. Next, select a different height and repeat the process for three different heights.  In activity 3, calculate the impact and rebound velocities of the individual heights. Then, calculate the average heights and velocities of the individual balls. Next, repeat these calculations for the stacked balls. In the extension activity, calculate the coefficient of restitution for the Tennis ball and the Ping-Pong ball.

pageData.desc: goggles symbol

pageData.text: Wear your safety goggles at all times while conducting this investigation. Read all the instructions for the activities before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment.
The experiment involves the dropping of various balls vertically, but the direction the balls may rebound can be random.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this investigation. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after the investigation and clean the work area with soap and water after finishing. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: When comparing the momentum of two moving objects, which of the following is most accurate?

options.text: The less massive object will have less momentum if the velocities of the two objects are equal.
The object with the higher velocity will have less momentum than the object with the lower velocity if their masses are equal.
The more massive object will have less momentum if its velocity is greater than that of the less massive object.
The more massive object will have less momentum if the velocities of the two objects are equal.
The less massive object will have less momentum if its velocity is greater than that of the more massive object.

assestmentData.question: Two skaters stand facing each other.  One skater’s mass is 60 kg and the other’s mass is 72 kg.  If the skaters push away from each other without spinning, which of the following statements will be true?

options.text: The momenta of the two skaters are equal but opposite.
The lighter skater has less momentum than the heavier skater.
The total momentum of the two skaters is less than the initial total momentum.
The total momentum of the two skaters is double the initial total momentum.
The momentum of the two skaters is inversely proportional to their respective masses.

assestmentData.question: In an elastic collision between two objects, which of the following states is true?

options.text: Both momentum and kinetic energy are conserved.
Momentum is conserved.
Kinetic energy is conserved.
Momentum is transferred into kinetic energy.
Neither momentum nor kinetic energy are conserved.

assestmentData.question: In an inelastic collision between two objects, which of the following statements is true?

options.text: Momentum is conserved.
Kinetic energy is conserved.
Momentum is transformed into kinetic energy.
Neither momentum nor kinetic energy is conserved.
Both momentum and kinetic energy are conserved.

assestmentData.question: An object initially at rest is dropped from the top of a building.  The object moves at 14.6 m/s as it approaches the ground.  What is the height of the building?<span className=bodyParaLineBreak> g = 9.8 m/s<sup>2</sup>

A 6.0 x 10<sup>-2</sup>  kg tennis ball moves at a velocity of -12 m/s toward a tennis player.  The ball is struck by the player with a racket causing the ball to rebound in the opposite direction (away from the player) at a speed of 18 m/s. What is the change in the ball’s momentum?

options.text: 1.8 kg m/s
-0.72 kg m/s
0 kg m/s
1.08 kg m/s
2.0 kg m/s

assestmentData.question: A 20.0 kg cannonball is fired from a 2.40 x 10<sup>3</sup> kg cannon.  If the cannon recoils with a velocity of -3.5 m/s, what is the velocity of the cannonball?

A tennis ball with a mass of 0.060 kg is dropped from a height of 0.75 meters.  It hits the floor and rebounds to a height of 0.58 meters.  What is the velocity of the tennis ball just before hitting the floor and just after hitting the floor?<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>  g = 9.80 m/s<sup>2</sup>

options.text: There is not enough information to calculate these velocities.

pageData.text: Use transparent tape to attach the metric measuring tape to the wall. Place the zero end of the tape at the floor, and extend the entire length of the measuring tape up the wall. (Caution: Be sure adhering and subsequent removal of the tape will not damage the finish on the wall.)
Use the electronic balance to determine the masses of the tennis ball and the Ping-Pong® ball. Record these values in Data Table 1 in the Lab Notebook.
In Activity 1, you will drop two different balls from different heights, record their rebounds and determine their rebound heights. You will perform calculations on this data in Activity 3.

typeBefore.text: Note: All measurements need to be recorded in SI units and contain the correct number of significant digits.
For this part of the lab, you will be dropping each sports ball individually to get an approximation of its rebound height.

pageData.text: Put on your safety goggles before attempting any ball drops.
pageData.desc: goggles symbol
pageData.altText: goggles symbol

pageData.text: Measure the initial drop height you will be using to drop a single ball. The initial drop height is measured from the floor to the bottom of the ball. Record your initial drop height in Data Table 2.
Using the tennis ball, place the bottom of the ball at your starting height h.
Start video recording, and drop the ball.
pageData.desc: record a video symbol
pageData.altText: record a video symbol

pageData.text: Repeat Steps 3 and 4 two more times for a total of three drops at the drop height h. You should have three consistent rebound heights. Repeat trials if needed.
Playback the video to determine the rebound height of each drop. Record these values in Data Table 2.
Using the Ping-Pong® ball, place the bottom of the ball at your starting height h. Use the height used for the tennis ball. Record your initial drop height in Data Table 3.
Start video recording, and drop the ball.
pageData.desc: record a video symbol
pageData.altText: record a video symbol

pageData.text: Repeat Steps 7 and 8 two more times for a total of three drops at the drop height h. You should have three consistent rebound heights. Repeat trials if needed.
Playback the video to determine the rebound height of each drop. Record these values in Data Table 3.

In Activity 2, you will drop two balls stacked on top of each other from different heights, record their rebounds and determine the rebound height of each ball.  You will perform calculations on this data in Activity 3.

typeBefore.text: For this part of the lab, you will be dropping two stacked sports balls (the tennis ball and the Ping-Pong<sup>®</sup> ball) and making height measurements to determine the impact and rebound velocities.

pageData.text: Put on your safety goggles before attempting any ball drops.
pageData.desc: goggles symbol
pageData.altText: goggles symbol

pageData.text: Measure and record the initial drop heights you will be using to drop the stacked sports balls. The initial drop height is measured from the floor to the bottom of the ball. (Note: As a result of the collision, the Ping-Pong® ball will rebound to a greater height than the measurements made in Activity 1.)
Record your initial drop heights in Data Table 4.
Place the Ping-Pong® ball on top of the tennis ball. (You will need to hold it in place prior to the drop.) Place the bottom of the tennis ball at your starting height h.
Start video recording. Drop the balls, releasing them both at the same time. It may take several attempts to get both balls to drop and rebound as described in the Background section.
pageData.desc: record a video symbol
pageData.altText: record a video symbol

pageData.text: Repeat Steps 4 and 5 another two times for a total of three drops at the drop height h. You should have three consistent rebound heights. Repeat trials if needed.
Playback the video to determine the rebound heights of the balls. Record these values in Data Table 4.
In Activity 3, you will calculate the impact and rebound velocities and average rebound heights for the individual balls in Activity 1 and the stacked balls in Activity 2.

Calculate the impact and rebound velocities of the tennis ball. These are the velocities just before the ball collides with the floor (impact velocity) and just after it rebounds from the floor (rebound velocity). Record these values in Data Table 2. Velocity is a vector; indicate the direction using the sign convention + for objects moving upward and – for objects moving downward.
Calculate the average heights and velocities. Record these values in Data Table 2.

Calculate the impact and rebound velocities of the Ping-Pong® ball. These are the velocities just before the ball collides with the floor (impact velocity) and just after it rebounds from the floor (rebound velocity). Record these values in Data Table 3. Velocity is a vector; indicate the direction using the sign convention + for objects moving upward and – for objects moving downward.
Calculate the average heights and velocities. Record these values in Data Table 3.

Using measurements from Data Table 4, calculate the impact and rebound velocities of the tennis ball and the initial velocity of the Ping-Pong® ball (Equations 6, 6a, 6b, 7, and 7a). Record these values in Data Table 4.

pageData.text: Calculate the average heights and velocities for each of the stacked ball drops. Record these values in Data Table 4.
In the Extension Activity, you will use the data from Activity 1 to determine the coefficient of restitution of the two balls.

Outcomes
  • Determine the coefficient of restitution of a tennis ball
  • Determine the coefficient of restitution of a Ping-Pong® ball
BackgroundSir Isaac Newton derived many mathematical equations and laws that help us make sense of what happens when two objects collide. One of these is Newton’s law of restitution, which states when two objects collide, their speeds after the collision depend on the material that make up the objects.

The measure of the colliding materials’ nature is represented by a number known as the <button class='glossary-text'>coefficient of restitution (COR)</button>. The value of the coefficient of restitution provides information on the elasticity of the collision. Collisions in which there is no loss of overall <button class='glossary-text'>kinetic energy</button> perfectly <button class='glossary-text'>elastic collisions</button>—have the maximum coefficient of restitution, COR = 1. Collisions where maximum kinetic energy is lost—perfectly <button class='glossary-text'>inelastic collisions</button>—have the minimum coefficient of restitution, COR = 0. Most real-life collisions fall somewhere in between 0 and 1.

The coefficient of restitution represents the ratio of speeds after and before an impact, taken along the line of the impact. A single object is often described as having a coefficient of restitution, although it is not an intrinsic property of an object. Consideration should be given to the second object. However, the definition assumes collisions with perfectly rigid and elastic objects. The coefficient of restitution is given by square root of kinetic energy after impact over the kinetic energy before impact (see Equation E1).

pageData.desc: Equation E1: COR equals begin square root begin fraction one half m v sup 2 over one half m u sup 2 end fraction end square root equals begin square root begin fraction v sup 2 over u sup 2 end fraction end square root equals begin fraction v over u end fraction
pageData.altText: Equation E1: COR equals begin square root begin fraction one half m v sup 2 over one half m u sup 2 end fraction end square root equals begin square root begin fraction v sup 2 over u sup 2 end fraction end square root equals begin fraction v over u end fraction

pageData.text: The coefficient can also be given the square root of the at bounce height over the potential energy at drop height (see Equation E2).

pageData.desc: Equation E2: COR equals begin square root begin fraction m g h over m g H end fraction end square root equals begin square root begin fraction h over H end fraction end square root
pageData.altText: Equation E2: COR equals begin square root begin fraction m g h over m g H end fraction end square root equals begin square root begin fraction h over H end fraction end square root

text: Describe how the momentum of a single ball changes as it free falls from a height of approximately 1 m, collides with a hard floor, and rebounds.

When the single ball (either the tennis ball or Ping-Pong<sup>®</sup> ball) hits the floor, a collision occurs between the ball and the floor.  Is the collision elastic or inelastic?  Describe how you determine whether a collision is elastic or inelastic.

In a closed system, the total momentum before a collision is equal to the total momentum after the collision.  Does your data from Activity 1- Single Ball Drop support this statement?  If not, explain why.

A Ping-Pong<sup>®</sup> ball and a tennis ball are dropped and there is a very small gap between them when the tennis ball hits the floor.  Indicate the directions of the momentums of the Ping-Pong<sup>®</sup> ball and the tennis ball after the tennis ball collides with the floor, but before the balls collide with each other.  (Drawing a diagram may be helpful.)

Explain why the rebound heights of the Ping-Pong<sup>®</sup> ball in Activity 2 – Stacked Ball Drop are greater than the rebound heights of the Ping-Pong<sup>®</sup> balls from Activity 1 – Single Ball Drop.
A golf club hits a golf ball and the golf ball’s flight reaches a maximum height of 5.48 m. Calculate the momentum of the golf ball at the maximum height if the mass of the golf ball is 0.459 kg.
A rock is dropped from a height of 2.00 m.

nestedOrderList: Determine the velocity of the rock just before it heights the ground.
If the momentum of the rock just before hitting the ground is 14.0 kg m/s, what is the mass of the rock?
Is the collision between the rock and the ground elastic or inelastic? Explain.

text: Compare your range of values for the coefficient of restitution for the tennis ball with the values in Table E1.  Are your values within the range?  If not, indicate by how much your values are out of this range and discuss why your values may be different.

Compare your range of values for the coefficient of restitution for the Ping-Pong<sup>®</sup> ball with the values in Table E1.  Are your values within the range?  If not, indicate by how much your values are out of this range and discuss why your values may be different.
For a perfectly elastic collision, there is no loss of overall kinetic energy. In the collision between the balls and the floor kinetic energy is lost.  Explain where the lost kinetic energy is.
Is the coefficient of restitution, COR, constant?  If not, explain why the COR would not be constant.

pageData.content: Experimental Design Diagram
pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow for the investigation. To prepare, attach a metric measuring tape to the wall and measure the masses of the balls. In activity 1, drop the ball from a height along the measuring tape. Then, record the ball drop and determine the rebound height of the ball. Next, select a different height. Repeat the trial for three different heights. Then, repeat the whole process with the other ball.   In activity 2, drop the stacked balls from a height along the measuring tape. Then, record the ball drop and determine the rebound heights of the balls. Next, select a different height and repeat the process for three different heights.  In activity 3, calculate the impact and rebound velocities of the individual heights. Then, calculate the average heights and velocities of the individual balls. Next, repeat these calculations for the stacked balls. In the extension activity, calculate the coefficient of restitution for the Tennis ball and the Ping-Pong ball.

data.title: Coefficient of restitution (COR)
data.content: An indicator of how much kinetic energy remains after a collision between two objects

data.title: Conservation of energy
data.content: Principle that states energy can neither be created or destroyed but can be transferred from one system to another, or can be transformed from one type to another

data.title: Conservation of momentum
data.content: Principle that states the total momentum  of a closed system is constant before and after events such as collisions

data.title: Elastic collision
data.content: A collision between bodies  in which the total kinetic energy and momentum is conserved

data.title: Gravitational potential energy
data.content: The potential energy an object has due to a change in its position when it is present in a gravitational field

data.title: Inelastic collision
data.content: A collision which kinetic energy is not conserved due to the action of internal friction

data.title: Kinetic energy
data.content: The energy which a body possesses by virtue of being in motion

data.title: Mechanical energy
data.content: All the energy an object has because of its motion and its position

data.title: Momentum
data.content: A vector quantity of motion of a moving body, measured as a product of its mass and velocity

data.title: Potential energy
data.content: The energy possessed by a body by virtue of its position relative to others
